title: What were the important developments in typography during the 20th century.
content:
Hi  
I'm studying Graphic Design and we are just about to start the typography module of the course and we have to write and essay on the important developments in typography during the 20th century. What do you think they were and why?

Thanks  
Ramelton
author: ramelton

comments.content: What do you think they were and why?
Nothing quite like asking someone else to do your research for you. Here's one hint: computers might be involved somewhere.

When I teach Type 2 (which I should call "Book Typography," but the school won't let me) at an arts college, I give them a pop quiz on world history about the 3rd class session. It has about 17 events from about 600 C.E. to the present. The students are to place them in chronological order and then they are to note the implications these events had on visual culture.

Good Lord, do they hate this exercise. They say "we're design students, not history students." I respond that the two are not to be separated.

To perhaps ease the pain a bit I include "instructor's birth" and "student's birth." No one has attributed anything of importance to my birth, which is fine and accurate. I have gotten some pleasingly egocentric predictions of student accomplishments. After the quizzes have been passed back to me and we begin to discuss them, I note that anyone who places my birth earlier than it is will automatically fail the quiz.

powers

_And still, we had to write essays and make research._

I would say that research skills were the most important thing I learned at university, and certainly the aspect of my education that I have made most persistent use of since.

_... all I was looking for was some friedly pointers ..._

At the very least, you could do a little research and float a few ideas that you think may be relevant, and see what others think of them.

in other words, getting other people to do your homework for you

Ramelton, you and the NOLA students are learning that you have to take some lumps if you want to play with the big boys. And Mr. Grumpleton hasn't even popped in here to give his thoughts yet.

20th Century schtuff not yet mentioned...  
Sans serif --\> Bauhaus/Modernism  
Phototypesetting  
Dry Transfer Type
not to mention The Apple Mac.

Erik Spiekermann

cheerio Queneau
PostScript, True Type, Open Type

Some key words to Google and search Wikipedia with: Monotype, Compugraphic, Linotype, Penta, Pagemaker, Aldus, TeX (search under Knuth if there are too many bad hits), Troff, photocomposition, Quark, and Letraset. Maybe others will add to this list, as it is just giving you direction, rather than doing your research for you.

Through technology, the ability to produce fonts faster than ever before - compare and contrast that with where the technology was at the turn of the century and how over time, photosetting - then digital - changed all that.

And that's just technology. It's not just technology.

20th century design movements reshaped the types we use in drastic ways. Just charting this evolution would make an incredible research paper; from bauhaus to ... garage fonts.

Businesswise: how was type bought, distributed, used - ATF, Linotype, Monotype - thru ITC - and compare that with where we were by around 2000.

You're gonna need a copy of Meggs' History book.

and

Stanley Morison and Beatrice Warde.

Those two should spice up a paper or two.

Pay no attention to the underemployed-by-choice, dear ramelton, the bad students of the past rise against the good ones of the future in every generation. That's the good and the bad, I leave the ugly for later;)

The arrival of the typewriter as a tool for the masses.  
The perfection to 1/10,000 of an inch accuracy of the mechanical punch cutting process.  
The development of the commercial photo composition machine.  
The automation of post-input typesetting.  
The invention of the cargo container and, the founding of Typophile.

I'll leave it to the student to follow these leads, because I agree with John H that research skills are one of educations greatest gifts. :)

Cheers!

“ What were the important developments in typography during the 20th century ”

The dongle, also known as the hardware key. Fonts in old printers were supplied in a cartridge that was 'plugged' in the printer.  
No cartridge, no type. Good old days.
